image.altText: Daniel Andrews speaks at press conference

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms the state will no longer host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to cost blowouts.

title.children: Victoria to axe Commonwealth Games plans, Daniel Andrews confirms

image.altText: A builder (man) leaning over while standing on the top part of a house frame

items.synopsis: The Queensland government has built 485 social homes in the past financial year, a figure social service groups have labelled "absolutely insufficient" given current housing needs.

title.children: Advocates fear the housing crisis is deepening as figures reveal construction shortfall

image.altText: A dingo standing on a sandy trail

items.synopsis: Recently there has been a spate of dingo attacks on K'gari island, off the Queensland coast.

title.children: What to do if a dingo approaches you or your kids on K'gari

image.altText: A buckled and damaged bridge

items.synopsis: The day started with two mysterious explosions on Putin's beloved Kerch bridge and ended with Russia withdrawing from a crucial deal to allow Ukrainian grain to pass through the Black Sea. Here's everything we know.

title.children: A furious Putin, a busted bridge and a torn-up deal: Russia and Ukraine's wild 24 hours explained

image.altText: Brain scans showing amyloid in Alzheimer's disease, with the shape of a head filled in with colour representing scan results

items.synopsis: Decades of research on Alzheimer's disease have started to come to fruition, with at least three new drugs demonstrating the first glimmers of promise.

title.children: 'Major breakthrough': Landmark study shows best signs yet that Alzheimer's can be slowed

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: Inflation is creating inflation. Unlike previous episodes where higher prices sparked wage breakouts, a large portion of our inflation is being driven by interest rate hikes, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Fossil fuel prices have collapsed. So why are we paying more for electricity?

image.altText: A soldier in protective camouflage gear ducks and holds his helmet as a mortar explodes into the sky behind him

items.synopsis: Predicting the shape and outcome of future wars is all but impossible. What matters is the ability to learn and adapt better than an adversary and that is Ukraine's next challenge, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Russia's war tactics keep evolving. If Ukraine is to emerge victorious, it needs to be faster

image.altText: A white man with no hair, dressed in a suit, sits behind a microphone with a concerned expression.

items.synopsis: The executives of one of Australia's leading consultancy firms are criticised for their unwillingness to share information and how they handle complaints of misconduct.

title.children: Deloitte CEO admits he should not be paid seven times as much as PM during Senate grilling

image.altText: black and white photo of woman jumping over tennis net

items.synopsis: She was a burgeoning talent in Australian tennis but almost 60 years after giving up the professional sport, Madonna Schacht hopes fashion can keep her fond memories alive.

title.children: Madonna Schacht was once named 'the most beautiful sportswoman'. Her iconic style has returned

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo stands with her arms crossed with a black background

items.synopsis: Thirty-eight of Victoria's most eminent legal practitioners have signed a letter condemning the comments of Premier Daniel Andrews and calling for a public apology following the closure of the special investigative office set up to probe the Lawyer X scandal.

title.children: Barristers condemn Daniel Andrews's comments over Lawyer X special investigation

image.altText: People stand around a large object on a beach

items.synopsis: The object, which washed up at Green Head — 250km north of Perth — is being treated as hazardous until its origins can be established.

title.children: Australian Space Agency says mysterious item on WA beach could be 'foreign' rocket part

image.altText: Farm workers picking fruit in the field.

items.synopsis: Linx Employment is under investigation as seasonal workers in Queensland allege they have not been given adequate hours and have been left homeless, without enough money to return home.

title.children: Labour hire company under investigation for alleged 'bullying', mistreatment of Pacific workers

image.altText: Landscape picture of red Kimberley hills and green valleys at sunset

items.synopsis: Aboriginal groups hold some form of ownership over about half of Australia's landmass — and observers say the country's energy transition cannot happen without them.

title.children: Traditional owners embrace being 'at the forefront' of Australia's green energy superpower plans

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: Wall Street gained on optimism about good company profit results and the ASX is set to fall. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US stocks rally on company profit hopes, RBA minutes in focus, ASX set to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ and Roy Morgan say consumer confidence decreased by 0.7 per cent last week to 72.6 as Australians worry about the economy. It was the third fall in consumer confidence in a row with the confidence among the worst levels since the COVID-19 outbreak. Confidence fell in New South Wales and Victoria, but increased in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. ANZ says people are worried about high inflation and financial conditions. Confidence in current financial conditions fell by 5.7 points, while confidence that it was a good time to buy a major household item dropped by 0.8 per cent, after a 6.8 per cent fall in the previous week. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says confidence among renters was at a record low, while it improved for those paying off their homes. "The confidence level was among the five worst results since the COVID outbreak and has stayed below 80 for 20 straight weeks." "The decline in the latest result was mainly driven by weaker confidence in ‘current financial conditions" " Among the housing cohorts, confidence fell to a record low for those renting." "It improved among those paying off their homes but remained below 70, while it fell for those who own their homes outright."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence falls again

children.content: ANZ and Roy Morgan say consumer confidence decreased by 0.7 per cent last week to 72.6 as Australians worry about the economy.
It was the third fall in consumer confidence in a row with the confidence among the worst levels since the COVID-19 outbreak.
Confidence fell in New South Wales and Victoria, but increased in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia.
Consumer confidence
(ANZ Roy Morgan)
ANZ says people are worried about high inflation and financial conditions.

Confidence in current financial conditions fell by 5.7 points, while confidence that it was a good time to buy a major household item dropped by 0.8 per cent, after a 6.8 per cent fall in the previous week.
ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says confidence among renters was at a record low, while it improved for those paying off their homes.
"The confidence level was among the five worst results since the COVID outbreak and has stayed below 80 for 20 straight weeks."
"The decline in the latest result was mainly driven by weaker confidence in ‘current financial conditions"
" Among the housing cohorts, confidence fell to a record low for those renting."
"It improved among those paying off their homes but remained below 70, while it fell for those who own their homes outright."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Council of Trade Unions has called on the incoming Reserve Bank governor to review the central bank's thinking on unemployment and wages. ACTU secretary Sally McManus says low unemployment has not caused wages to surge over the past two years. Incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock says the unemployment rate needs to rise to 4.5 per cent to bring inflation down to the RBA's target of 2 to 3 per cent. But Ms McManus has told Patricia Karvalas on RN Breakfast that the RBA needs to update its understanding of how the wage system works. "We've had unemployment much lower than 4.5 per cent." "It's gone below 3.5 per cent and wages haven't gone up as a result."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACTU calls for RBA rethink on wages

featuredLink.title: Rise in unemployment expected to fight inflation - ABC Radio National

children.content: The Australian Council of Trade Unions has called on the incoming Reserve Bank governor to review the central bank's thinking on unemployment and wages.
ACTU secretary Sally McManus says low unemployment has not caused wages to surge over the past two years.
Incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock says the unemployment rate needs to rise to 4.5 per cent to bring inflation down to the RBA's target of 2 to 3 per cent.
But Ms McManus has told Patricia Karvalas on RN Breakfast that the RBA needs to update its understanding of how the wage system works.
"We've had unemployment much lower than 4.5 per cent."
"It's gone below 3.5 per cent and wages haven't gone up as a result."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe says governments need to do more to tackle falling productivity. He's used his final international appearance at a G20 finance meeting in India, alongside Treasurer Jim Chalmers, to warn about slowing productivity growth. Mr Lowe says falling productivity is a bigger challenge than inflation. "The reality that most of us face is that productivity growth has slowed down in most of our economies," he said. "It means lower sustainable growth in real wages, it means a limited increase in output as well. "It means a slower expansion in the public services we want for our society and it means an increased tension in the distribution of income. "So low productivity growth means economic and social problems. "I agree the immediate consequence and the immediate challenge is to get inflation down. "We really need to be successful there but I think the bigger challenge is to lift productivity growth." Mr Lowe ends his seven-year term as Reserve Bank governor in September after he was not reappointed by the treasurer. His deputy Michele Bullock will become the first women to lead the RBA. Here's more from ABC News.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Philip Lowe says productivity greater challenge than inflation

featuredLink.title: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

children.content: Outgoing Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe says governments need to do more to tackle falling productivity.
He's used his final international appearance at a G20 finance meeting in India, alongside Treasurer Jim Chalmers, to warn about slowing productivity growth.
Mr Lowe says falling productivity is a bigger challenge than inflation.
"The reality that most of us face is that productivity growth has slowed down in most of our economies," he said.
"It means lower sustainable growth in real wages, it means a limited increase in output as well.
"It means a slower expansion in the public services we want for our society and it means an increased tension in the distribution of income.
"So low productivity growth means economic and social problems.
"I agree the immediate consequence and the immediate challenge is to get inflation down.
"We really need to be successful there but I think the bigger challenge is to lift productivity growth."
Mr Lowe ends his seven-year term as Reserve Bank governor in September after he was not reappointed by the treasurer.
His deputy Michele Bullock will become the first women to lead the RBA.
Here's more from ABC News.
